title: Preparation of RNAP E.coli for Structural Analysis of +39 Elongation Complex by Cryo-Electron Microscopy
content: Transcription is the first step of gene expression, which involves synthesis of RNA on DNA template performed by DNA-dependent RNA polymerases (RNAPs). Transcription occurs in three steps — initiation, elongation and termination. RNAPs are multi-subunit enzymes that catalyze the formation of phosphodiester bonds using ribonucleoside triphosphates as substrates and are structurally and functionally conserved among all three domains of life [1, 2]. Holoenzyme of multisubunit E. coli RNAP consists of a sigma factor (σ) and five subunits: two alpha (α) subunits, a small omega (ω) subunit, a beta (β) and a beta prime (β′) subunits, which together with the catalytic magnesium ion form the active site [3, 4]. The holoenzyme of E. coli RNAP is a classical model object for detailed structural studies [5, 6].
